response: Property was abandoned by mining company decades ago and is now owned by state (IRRRB).  Rebuild of trail over $1,000,000.
Drill was stopped, the hole was grouted and the situation returned to "normal". Reservoir was lowered and an emergency seepage collection system and stability butress were constructed.
Directed owner to clear debris, repair erosion.
Owner did some stabilization work on sloughing and hired an engineering consultant to do additional analysis
COFFERDAM CONSTRUCTED; A 20' BOTTOM WIDTH BREACH CHANNEL EXCAVATED TO DRAIN BY MAY 11
Response hindered as this was an illegal dam previously unknown to the Division of Safety of Dams until days after the event.
OWNER NOW AGREES TO REMOVE DAM & WILL BE ISSUED EMERGENCY PERMIT WITH SPECIFIED BREACH SIZE
Owner contacted local EMC when water was within 5-ft of the crest, residents downstream evacuated
The seepage was repaired using additional cutoffs and relief drains and the sink hole was repaired.

State Dam Safety Program performed a full inspection following the breach of this dam.  The inspection report will contain a requirement that the Owner hire an engineer and submit either a permit application for repair or removal of the dam.

Collum contacted the Tombigbee River Valley Water Management District about repairs as they had previously repaired the structure.

A DETAILED BREACH ANALYSIS IN 2016 USING LIDAR SHOWED DOWNSTREAM HOMES ARE NOT IMPACTED BY A DAM FAILURE.
Owner had contractor cut a new spillway over natural ground to help drain and prevent failure.

Worked with EMA and responders to plug the piping failure until permanent repairs could be made.
Work was done to lower the reservoir and to try to stabilize the headcut.

work with owner to remove valve and allow reservoir to drain full and stream to run through the conduit until such time as the outlet works can be removed and replaced

owner contacted TCEQ that the spillway had failed and the reservoir was not holding water, TCEQ inspected
Road over dam closed and temporary repairs done quickly. Lake drain then opened to keep lake low.

Lake water was released through the internal pipe in the dam to the downstream and lake level was lowered. The dam didn't break. Fairfax County opened the low level drain and drained the lake to remove the hazard.

owner was onsite during high flow event and monitored the situation.  Did not activate the EAP.

response: Notified State official and the on-call engineer right away. Started pumping the seepage collection pond, suspended plant operation and mobilized construction equipments to construct additional seepage berms and buttress to the dam embankment.

Directed owner to have conduit replaced.
restrictred water level and observation
After contact with owner, beaver dams were cleared weeks after overtopping incident.

Water levels at the dam as well as a downstream dam were lowered, and the seepage stopped.

EXTENSIVE SOIL TESTING AND REDESIGN OF THE REHABILITATION PROJECT.

DEP INSPECTOR VISIT TO DAM ON THE NEXT MORNING CONFIRMED NO CHANGE IN PRE-EXISTING SEEPAGE.

FEDERAL DAM WITH NO STATE JURISDICTION.  OWNER NOTIFIED CAMPGROUND DOWNSTREAM.

Increased monitoring of the spillway until water levels decreased, an in-depth spillway inspection and assessment was done Summer 2019, temporary repair was completed in Spring 2020, an updated breach analysis was done, and owner has  started planning on a full replacement.

No EAP but local officials were notified. The dam owner was very cooperative. They were able to get a contractor on site relatively quickly and agreed with our plan of action. The County SWCD office keeped us up-to-date with the progess after the initial emergency was over.

County elected to lower lake level to reduce risk presented by structure until repairs can be completed.
Owners activitated EAP and closely monitored the site.  Barricaded and signed to prevent entry to public.

Lake has been drained and temporary armored channel has been cut through embankment as interim measure until permanent repair or decommissioning can be completed.
County officials shut down one lane of traffic and maintained a lowered lake level until repairs could be completed.  New culverts installed and backslope regraded and armored with grouted riprap.

Sent staff several times. Owner was able to draw the water level down and eventually replace the spillway.

The Ohio Dam Safety Program (ODSP) was contacted by the dam owner. They started monitoring the seepage and opened the lake drain.
Dam safety staff notified by local enforcement and DNR conservation warden.  Contacted owner to monitor and further activate EAP if needed.
The water level in the pond has been lowered and the low level outlet is being used to pass flows.  An emergency design to repair the spillway is being done.
DRAWDOWN OF RESERVOIR, APPROX. 1 FOOT/DAY.  REPAIR MEASURES IN PLANNING.
DAM WAS REPAIRED AFTER THE FLOOD AND REMAINED IN SERVICE.
ODSP staff directed the dam owner to lower the water level. Started by pumping and then was able to remove a portion of the spillway riser. Dam currently under design.
Sent staff to observe sinkhole. Dam was already drained from previous incidents. Directed owner to partially breach dam until dam can be brought into full compliance.
Emergency pumping and partial removal of riser to clear blockage
Owner notified downstream neighbor immediately.
Siphoned the water level down. Dam owner is looking into breaching the dam.
Dam owner notified sheriff and sheriff checked on D/S properties and notified property owners.
USACE supplied high capacity pump, city and county placed rock in void to slow failure
Owner cleaned out spillway drain and seepage around spillway side wall stopped
Pool level subsided
Quickly installed a temporary buttress, got pumps running and initiated a more diligent monitoring plan for the pumps, generators and slopes.
PRIMARY SPILLWAY PLUGGED, FLOW DIVERTED TO AUXILIARY PIPES, & REPAIR PLAN PREPARED.
